Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 06:22AM ango74 wrote: I was also just diagnosed.  I'm not huge but I'm a nice C cup and I've also worried about having a miss matched pair. I'm not so much worried about size not matching up exactly but I'm worried about perkiness.  To be honest mine are a bit saggy for my age (33).  Have you sat down with a plastic surgeon yet?  I haven't.  My friend who went through this last yr said it made a huge differnece when she sat down with the plastic surgeon.  I am 99 % sure I am going to have both done.  I don't know if our chances are any higher from having it now but I NEVER want to have to hear "you have cancer" again.  I feel like if I keep my left one I am going to be eaten up with worry that I have cancer in it.  I just don't want to live like that. Having both done is the right choice for me, I am comfortable with it.  You have to do what makes you comfortable, what you can live with in the long run. Take Care! Angie

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 07:04PM ango74 wrote: Frankie, The AE37/GP2 vaccine is for Her2 +.   It is suppose to reduce the chance of recurrence. It is in stage II now. I go every 3 wks and get 4 shots, 2 of each AE37 and GP2 peptide. In a nut shell this is raising your cancer fighting cells and teaching it to fight the Her2 + protien.  This is a good link explaining the trial although it is from when it was still in Phase l. http://journals.lww.com/oncology-times/Fulltext/2009/02250/GP2_and_AE37_HER_2_neu_Peptide_Vaccines_Show.20.aspx

Posts.Content: May 2, 2013 10:29PM ango74 wrote: I started Tykerb and Zeloda about 6 months into my stage IV journey.  I am now on it again (2yrs later) with Abraxane and Herceptin.  Don't know if it's working yet.  I was due for scans a about 3 weeks ago but found out about brain mets and am now just on hercetpin while doing that. formygirls-I have not heard of taking Tykerb like this but I plan on bringing it up at my next visit.  I had to cut my dose back due to side effects but have brain mets so if a higher dose helps with that than I will deal with the side effects.
Posts.Title: Tykerb Question sueopp hendricks1

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2012 11:03AM ango74 wrote: Maxerpaws, I didn't get the 6-8 months to live but I did get the "get your stuff in order" talk. I have been on several chemos and nothing worked. If you go on the adriamycin you will be eligable for the TDM1/Theresa trial. Here is a link to the trial. I just started it about 2 weeks ago. If your not familar with TDM1....google it.  It has been doing amazing things for Her2 + women. http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01419197?term=tdm+1&rank=17 There is another trial with amazing results. It includes, TDM 1, Pertuzumab and Taxol but there are only a handfull of places doing this trial. Here's the link for that one too. http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01276041?term=pertuzumab&rank=2 Plus Pertuzumab is FDA approved now for Her2+ cancer and seems to work when Herceptin and Tykerb have failed. There is still hope. Take care!

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 11:06AM ango74 wrote: Harmony, I really like my surgeon.  He has stayed late after work calling my insurance, getting things approved, calling some of his doctor friends at home to get me quick appointments.  He is great! The only issue I have with him is that I want both done and he has refused to do the left.  He says "your too young".  I have had my oncologist call him, the plastic surgeon and my obgyn to try to talk him into doing both.  He now says he will consider the other but he will not do them at the same time.  Now, my lymph nodes in the left side arm pit have started swelling so I have to go for another scan on monday to see whats going on.  My onco said this my sway him into doing both.  Do you like your surgeon? Will you do reconstruction later?

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 09:19AM - edited Aug 4, 2011 03:34PM by ango74 When I was first diagnosised with stage IIIc I told everyone, everything.  Now that I'm stage IV, I only tell on a need to know basis. I don't tell my husband as much as I use to, he tunes me out most of the time and the stuff he listens to he just forgets later on. lol.  I have a 14 yr old and 5 yr old. I don't talk too much to them about it.  They have other worries with school and such but I do keep them informed when there are changes.  When I do talk to my friends about it I try to keep it short and sweet. I like Fitzs idea about emailing DH updates.  I might try this out, that way DH can't say "I didn't tell me, I don't remember you telling me".

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2011 05:52PM ango74 wrote: Tumor markers can be such a pain in the butt!  One time my CA /29/27 was 85 so we ran scans and there was nothing.  When it was 21 (lowest it's ever been) I was diagnosised with Stage IV.  I don't even ask what mine are now.  My onco also told me it depends who is running the test.  She said you can have a difference of about 10 depending on the lab that runs it.  I hope yours is just a freak thing, hang in there.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 10:39AM ango74 wrote: I also had a bad reaction.  It wasn't hives but it was a severe rash (bumps, red skin, burning and horrible itching) from head to toe.  It was on my scalp, in my ears, on my eye lids.....everywhere. My dr. told me she had never seen the reaction that bad.  They took my off it for about 2 weeks put me on a steriod and then we started it back up. I haven't had that bad of a reaction since then but I still get a burning itching on my arms everyday about an hour after taking it but it's doable.  Plus it's working so I will deal with it.  Like everyone else has said get to your dr. asap. There is a lot of info on this site about the Tykerb rash and reactions.  Hope it gets better.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 10:50PM ango74 wrote: I'm in the same boat right now Ann. Just started Adriamycin, Cytoxin and Herceptin, today is day 15 and I am sheading like crazy.  For some reason it bothers me more this time than it did the first time.   I went out the other day and bought a cute new wig, it cheered me up a tiny bit. The first time around I bought the most comfortable wig and it was pretty cute too. I wore it all the time, this time  I will only wear the wig if I have to go up to the kids school or if they have friends over.  It's harder in the summer for me because most of my caps are too hot, the wigs are also hot so I will give scarves a go this time around.

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 08:08PM ango74 wrote: I just finished my 3rd month of Navelbine.  I get 3 weeks Navelbine/herceptin and then 1 wk Herceptin only.  My hair didn't thin at all, altough I heard it can.  My worse side effect so far is constipation which seems to effect a lot of ppl on it. I'm a little more tired than normal but it is hard to tell if that is from my kids hectic schedule of the treatment probabaly a little of both. Take care.

Posts.Content: May 29, 2012 09:46AM ango74 wrote: Happy Birthday to your daughter!  I have a hard time with birthdays and holidays too. There is always that "is this my last one".  My daughter is going to be 15 in about 2 weeks, I am having her party this weekend.  For some reason this birthday is easier than the last ones have been. Maybe because I've been too busy planning it that I really haven't thought.... this could be my last one with her.  I have a 6 yr old too and a few weeks ago we went to a birthday party for his little school friend and all I could think was how lucky the mom was to have so many birthday parties to look forward to with her son.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 12:48PM ango74 wrote: I am also stage IV, 37 and have two kiddo's ages 6 and one that is almost 15.  I have also gotten the "oh I know what you are going through" but I get that usually from people who don't even have cancer, maybe a relative but they have never walked down the road themselves.   Those are the ones that bother me the most....they have no idea.  I think when people say that it is because they don't know what else to say and they want to be comforting.  No matter what their reasoning is, it still stings.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2012 04:48PM ango74 wrote: I was on Adriamycin, cytoxin and herceptin over the summer.  I didn't really have any problems with it and actually found it to be one of the easier regimens I've had.  I felt the usual fatigue and flu like symptoms for about 2-3 days afterwards.  I kept up with my nausea meds so I didn't really have problem with that but I know that to be a common symptom. Good luck with it, hope it kicks your cancer in it's rear and that your side effects are mild.
